content: Hey, I'm back. The lab went well, finally got that data structure algorithm to work.
Hey Ethan, great to hear! It's always a good feeling when the code finally clicks. Was it a tricky one?
Yeah, it was a recursive sorting algorithm for my advanced algorithms class. Took me and a friend, Sarah, a few hours of whiteboarding and debugging.
Teamwork makes the dream work! Having a friend to bounce ideas off of is invaluable. Is Sarah in many of your classes?
Yeah, we're in the same study group. It's much easier to stay motivated when you have people to hold you accountable.
That makes total sense. So, that feeling of solving a complex problemâ€”is that the main thing that drives you in CS?
That's a huge part of it. The other is just the pure act of creation. Seeing an idea turn into a functional app is my biggest motivation.
That's a great driver. Speaking of which, how's the Python note web app coming along? Last time you were just getting started.
It's progressing. I've built the basic backend logic for creating, editing, and deleting notes. Now I'm trying to implement a more efficient database query system.
Diving deep into the backend, I see. What database technology are you using for it?
I'm using PostgreSQL. I find its documentation really clear and it's powerful for what I need. I want to add full-text search later, and it's great for that.
A solid choice with future-proofing in mind. Very smart. So when you're not deep in code, what have you been up to?
Not much, honestly. Midterms are next month, so I'm starting to feel the pressure. That's starting to stress me out a bit.
Midterms are definitely a major stressor. I remember you mentioned exams bother you. How are you feeling about them overall?
A bit anxious, but I've started planning my study schedule. Trying to stay on top of it so it doesn't become overwhelming.
That proactive approach is the best way to handle it. Does listening to your electronic music help with studying too, or just coding?
It helps with studying too, as long as it's instrumental. Anything without lyrics works. Recently I've been listening to a lot of Aphex Twin and Boards of Canada.
Excellent choices for focus! Very atmospheric. So, being a second-year student, you're probably around 20, right?
Yep, I just turned 20. Feeling old already with all these assignments piling up.
Haha, I hear that. It's important to take breaks. Are you still making time for the piano?
I try to. I make sure to play for about 30 minutes every evening to decompress. It's a non-screen activity which really helps my eyes and mind relax.
That's a fantastic habit. What kind of music do you enjoy playing?
Mostly classical pieces. Right now, I'm trying to learn Chopin's Nocturne in E-flat major. It's challenging but so beautiful.
That's a gorgeous piece. It requires a lot of emotional expression. It's interesting how you listen to electronic but play classical.
I guess they serve different purposes. Electronic music helps me think logically and stay in a flow state. Classical music helps me disconnect and feel something different.
That's a very insightful way to put it. You've clearly built a good system for managing your focus and relaxation. What about social life? Do you get time for that?
Not as much during the pre-midterm crunch. Mostly just study sessions with my group. We might grab a quick bite after, but that's about it.
It's good that you're prioritizing, though. What about those sci-fi movies? Have you seen anything good lately?
I re-watched 'Blade Runner 2049' last weekend. The cinematography and world-building are just incredible. I'm a huge fan of Denis Villeneuve's work.
He's a master of atmosphere. It seems like you gravitate towards things that are immersive, both in music and film.
Yeah, I guess I do. I like things that pull you into a different headspace. It's a form of escape, I suppose.
A healthy one, at that. Well, it sounds like you have a solid plan for the upcoming weeks. You should probably get back to that study plan.
Yeah, you're right. It was good to chat and get my thoughts in order though.
Anytime. Break a leg with the planning, Ethan. Talk soon!
Thanks, catch you later.
You got it.
